body: 5 epochs are not probably enough and the network outputs are out of the range. Let it train more and try again. Something would be visible around 25k iterations with larger enough dataset. Let me know the result.

@zfallahnejad I skimmed your code. Itlookslike your dataset is small. I'm not sure this size would be enough. Also at the validation phase keep an eye on "Decoder stopped with 'max_decoder_steps". It means, your model did not learn enough, and even it doesn't know where to stop in voice synthesis. You can only have good results after this line disappears.

You're right. Five epochs are not enough. I just want to make sure that there is no error, then I will train for more epochs.
I have 4692 audio files along with their transcripts in my dataset. I used 10 different audiobooks from 10 different speakers to prepare this dataset. Audio files vary in length from 1.5 to 10 seconds and have a total length of approximately 8.5 hours. I want to use this dataset for training a Speech-to-Text model like `deepspeech`. Then, I decided to take a subset of these audio files which belongs to a single speaker and train a Text-to-Speech model like TTS. I take 915 audio files (5769 seconds) of my dataset and trained 'TTS' for a few epoch as you saw before. I read somewhere that "two hours of dataset is enough for `wavenet` to generate crystal clear quality of audio", so I thought this subset can be good enough for the first try. What do you think? How much hours of dataset required to train a TTS model and produce good quality of voice?

I suggest you to use a single speaker dataset . I never tried TTS with multiple speakers yet. Until speaker embedding is implemented, it does not really make sense. I think, if you can find a single speaker dataset 8.5 hours would be enough for simple sentences but beyond that needs more data. My experience tells > 20 hours for a solid model depending on recording quality, word vocabulary size and so.

If you need to use the data at hand, then you can introduce a new layer which takes the user ID as an input to differentiate speakers. That would be quite easy to implement. If you are opt to, I can also provide some help for your questions.
Sorry. I forgot to mention such an important detail in my previous post. I take 915 audio files (5769 seconds) of my dataset which belongs to a single speaker.

so then it is too small to train a strong model. Try TTS, would be interesting to see on such a small dataset but I'd not keep a validation split. Hope it works at least to a level. 

If you are probing a european language dataset with no success, you can check http://www.caito.de/2019/01/the-m-ailabs-speech-dataset/

@erogol I'm now trying with Mandarin Chinese, and found the result is really good !  But when at training and synthesis stages, `Decoder stopped with 'max_decoder_steps'` will sometimes occurs, and when at synthesis process, the server will be dead for a long time and the synthesis result cannot stop correctly.

I skimmed your implementation and still confused how could it happens, and how to solve it.

```Decoder stopped with 'max_decoder_steps'``` means model does not know where to stop and it reached the given threshold. Therefore it takes longer in this case, if it is what you mean. Until model converges and start to align, it will happen. You can skip this test sentence synthesis until your model learns and you can activate it afterwards.

I have trained the system using the LJSpeech-1.1 dataset for 500 epochs. I has taken few days to finish on a Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 5115 CPU @ 2.40GHz with a GeForce GTX TITAN.

However, running the Benchmark.ipynb notebook gives me:

"ParameterError: Audio buffer is not finite everywhere".

Any ideas what is going wrong or how to debug the problem?
@ntsourakis have you checked your results on Tensorboard ? I think your model is not trained well, especially attention part so it cannot generalize for test cases.

Thank you@erogol.

Yes, I have checked the results on TB. Here it the output: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7830603/52275136-f66c6e80-294e-11e9-9464-b632f39ec961.png)

From your own experience does this seem to be good enough? It will be helpful to have some documentation for your TB graphs.

When I used your trained model 'November-04-2018_06+19PM-TTS-master-_tmp-debug' I do not get the same graphs on TB to compare. Is it possible to create a new version?

Benchmark.ipynb doesn't work for me but I can produce sentences with the TTS server for both my model and yours (the latter sounds better).

--

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7830603/52345889-9513d080-2a1e-11e9-8423-aa4eab3fb851.png)

I had to do few changes in the Benchmark.ipynb but the problem persists. E.g.:
CONFIG.num_freq -> CONFIG.audio['num_freq']

Anyway, for the time being I can use the TTS server to check the quality of my model.

Is it possible to generate a new run in the google drive? The one for LJSpeech-1.1 is not well alligned with the current version of the repo.

Of course any kind of documentation would be more than welcome!
@ntsourakis it does not seem bad but not the best either. I don't know in that case. The error states that the predicted values are out of range to be converted to audio.
